statement.text: Toe amputation is a minor amputation technique that can preserve foot function while removing necrotic or non-salvageable tissue, with success dependent on adequate perfusion and infection control.
statement.formal: Types: Distal phalanx, MTP disarticulation, ray amputation; Perfusion requirement: TP >30mmHg, TcPO2 >30mmHg; Healing rate: 60-80% with adequate perfusion

explanation.intuition: When gangrene is limited to a toe, removing just that toe can stop the infection from spreading while preserving foot function. The key is ensuring enough blood flow exists to heal the surgical wound.
explanation.key_insight: The goal of toe amputation is to remove only what is necessary while maximizing remaining foot function - level selection is critical.
explanation.technical_details: Toe amputation encompasses several techniques: distal phalanx amputation (for tip necrosis), middle phalanx amputation, metatarsophalangeal (MTP) disarticulation, and ray amputation (toe plus metatarsal head). The choice depends on extent of gangrene, infection, and perfusion. Great toe amputation significantly impacts gait; preserving as much as possible is beneficial. Adequate perfusion (toe pressure >30 mmHg, TcPO2 >30 mmHg) predicts healing. Wound should be left open or loosely approximated if infection is present.
common_misconceptions: All gangrenous toes need immediate amputation - FALSE, dry gangrene can autoamputate if infection controlled
Toe amputation is always minor - FALSE, great toe amputation significantly affects gait
Amputation level doesn't matter - FALSE, higher amputation reduces stump function
Closure is always required - FALSE, often left open or loosely closed

absolute: Dry gangrene limiting function or hygiene
Osteomyelitis of phalanges not responding to treatment
relative: Painful digital ischemia limiting quality of life

mtp_disarticulation.technique: Disarticulate at MTP joint, racquet incision
mtp_disarticulation.great_toe_consideration: Preserve base of proximal phalanx if possible

ray_amputation.technique: Remove toe plus portion of metatarsal

closure.clean_wound: Loose primary closure or secondary intention

bone_management.flap_coverage: Ensure soft tissue covers bone end

wound_management: Transition to less frequent as healing progresses

great_toe.importance: Critical for push-off phase of gait

multiple_toes.consideration: May need TMA if multiple rays involved

definition.@value: Surgical removal of one or more toes to eliminate necrotic tissue while preserving foot function.

presentation: Ischemic rest pain localized to digit

learning_objectives: Select appropriate amputation level based on gangrene extent
Assess perfusion adequacy for wound healing
Describe technical aspects of toe amputation
clinical_pearls: Great toe loss significantly impacts gait - preserve when possible
Wet gangrene needs urgent amputation; dry gangrene can be observed
Leave wounds open if infected - never close a dirty wound
Revascularize before amputation if perfusion is marginal
